newsitem.title: UK: Sugar freight business calmer but Far East active.
newsitem.headline: Sugar freight business calmer but Far East active.

text.p: New sugar freight business was thin on the ground on Friday as the market took space to breathe after this week's rush of fixtures, shipbrokers said.
"The East has been quite busy...Indonesia has been the star of the week," said one, citing fixtures of Thai sugar by Kerry, E D & F Man and other charterers.
"It's very slow -- the Far East business is picking up with Thailand-Indonesia and Thailand-Japan. The Brazil and Continent markets are both very quiet," said another.
The only new business reported was on the account of Benham or nominee, quoting for 18,814 tonnes in bulk from Taiwan to Crockett for 5/15 February.
The Taiwan Sugar Corp announced a tender for January 30 in New York for a 30,000-tonne shipment of raw sugar to fulfil its fiscal buying plan.
The tender, which falls on January 31 Taiwan time, will specify April 20 to May 5 delivery dates.
Taiwan Sugar has bought 90,000 tonnes of sugar in the fiscal year to date, including 60,000 tonnes arranged through a three-year supply deal negotiated privately with Czarnikow Sugar.
The deal took effect in 1997 but leaves Taiwan Sugar 30,000 tonnes short of fulfilling its 120,000 tonne fiscal purchasing plan.
Colombian truckers demanding standby payments for time lost during a nine-day dockworkers' strike in Buenaventura prevented work from returning to normal on Friday.
The dockworkers returned to work on Friday morning, a day after winning a deal with shipowners and cargo handling operators that should more than double their wages.
